Authors:
Andreia Mitsa Paiva Negreiros, Rui Sales Junior, Maela
Leon, Naama Jessica de Assis Melo, Sami Jorge Michereff, Marcia M.Q.
Ambrosio, Hohanna L.S. Medeiros, Josep Armengol
Title:
Identification and pathogenicity of Macrophomina species
collected from weeds in melon fields in Northeastern Brazil
Keywords:
Boerhavia diffusa, Macrophomina phaseolina, Macrophomina
pseudophaseolina, Trianthema portulacastrum
Abstract:
In this work, a collection of 94 Macrophomina spp.
isolates obtained from roots of two weed species, Trianthema
portulacastrum and Boerhavia diffusa, collected during a survey
conducted during 2015 and 2016 in melon production fields in
Northeastern Brazil, were characterized by using phenotypical and
molecular techniques. Phylogenetic analysis of the TEF gene, amplified
with the primers EF728F and EF986R, allowed the identification of 62
isolates as M. pseudophaseolina and 32 as M. phaseolina. Both M.
phaseolina and M. pseudophaseolina showed high optimum mycelial growth
temperatures: 29.85 and 30.59 °C, respectively, and they were able to
grow at 40 °C. Results of a pathogenicity test performed on melon
seedlings of the cv. ‘Gladial’ revealed that the two species were able
cause disease to melon, but M. phaseolina presented higher disease
incidence and severity than M. pseudophaseolina. This study represents
the first report of M. pseudophaseolina in T. portulacastrum and B.
diffusa weeds, which are prevalent in the main Brazilian producing and
exporting regions of melon. This is also the first report of this fungus
in Brazil. Information about the biology, epidemiology and geographical
distribution of M. pseudophaseolina is scarce because of its recent
description, thus further research is needed for a better understanding
of this fungus as a potentially emerging pathogen of melon and other
crops,and about how to manage it.
